affenpinscher.nature: Fearless, curious, affectionate, loyal, playful, independent (often called 'monkey-dog' for its face).
affenpinscher.food_diet: High-quality, balanced nutrition tailored for a small breed. Two small meals per day. Formulas supporting dental and joint health are recommended.
affenpinscher.health_care: Regular brushing and professional clipping/stripping. Weekly ear and dental care. Monitor breathing and restrict exercise in hot weather (brachycephalic). Daily walks and playtime.
affenpinscher.size: Height: 23–30 cm (9–12 in); Weight: 3–6 kg (7–13 lb)
affenpinscher.common_health_issues: Patellar luxation (knee issues), hip dysplasia, brachycephalic airway syndrome, heart murmurs, dental disease, cataracts.

afghan_hound.nature: Elegant, dignified, aloof, independent, sweet, and can be 'silly' or clownish with family. Reserved with strangers.
afghan_hound.food_diet: High-quality, protein-heavy diet, moderate in fat, and low in carbohydrates. Adult: 2–2.5 cups of dry food daily, split into two meals. Prone to bloat (GDV).
afghan_hound.health_care: Daily brushing/combing for long, silky coat. Regular bathing. High-fenced yard and 1–2 hours of high-intensity exercise per day. Sensitive to anesthesia.
afghan_hound.size: Height: 63–74 cm (25–29 in); Weight: 20–27 kg (44–60 lb)
afghan_hound.common_health_issues: Hip dysplasia, bloat (GDV), laryngeal paralysis, juvenile cataracts, sensitivity to anesthesia.

airedale.nature: Confident, intelligent, friendly, courageous, and energetic. Bold and stubborn with a high drive for chasing, digging, and barking.
airedale.food_diet: High-quality, high-protein dog food, divided into two smaller meals per day. Portion control and small, frequent meals are crucial to prevent obesity and bloat (GDV).
airedale.health_care: Weekly brushing; professional stripping/clipping 3–4 times per year. 60–90 minutes of vigorous exercise daily. Dental care is important.
airedale.size: Height: 56–61 cm (22–24 in); Weight: 18–29 kg (40–65 lb)
airedale.common_health_issues: Hip dysplasia, hypothyroidism, cancer, allergies, bloat (GDV), cataracts, glaucoma.

american_staffordshire_terrier.nature: Affable, smart, loyal, and protective of family. Confident and sometimes prone to dog-aggression if not socialized.
american_staffordshire_terrier.food_diet: High-quality diet appropriate for age and activity level, focusing on lean protein. Obesity is a significant risk, so portion control and consistency are vital. Feed adult dogs twice daily.
american_staffordshire_terrier.health_care: Low grooming needs; weekly brushing. Regular dental care (twice weekly brushing). High energy needs, requires daily vigorous exercise and mental stimulation. Early obedience and socialization are essential.
american_staffordshire_terrier.size: Height: 43–48 cm (17–19 in); Weight: 25–34 kg (55–75 lb) - AKC standard is relative to height and balance.
american_staffordshire_terrier.common_health_issues: Hip and elbow dysplasia, knee ligament tears, hypothyroidism, cerebellar ataxia (inherited neurological disorder), cardiac disease, skin allergies.

appenzeller.nature: Bright, loyal, lively, energetic, and protective. Can be wary of strangers and has a high tendency to bark (alert nature).
appenzeller.food_diet: High-quality canine diet, with the amount and type of food tailored by a vet to their age and high activity level. Prone to bloat (GDV), so feeding practices must minimize risk (e.g., elevated bowl, avoid pre/post-exercise feeding).
appenzeller.health_care: Short, smooth double coat has low grooming needs. Requires high levels of daily exercise (long walks, running, hiking) and mental stimulation. Early and thorough socialization is crucial due to wariness of strangers.
appenzeller.size: Height: 48–56 cm (19–22 in); Weight: 22–32 kg (48–70 lb)
appenzeller.common_health_issues: Hip dysplasia, elbow dysplasia, bloat (Gastric Dilatation-Volvulus), and arthritis (though generally considered a very healthy breed).

australian_terrier.nature: Spirited, courageous, and affectionate companion. Friendly and playful, with a classic terrier high prey drive and tendency to bark (good watchdog).
australian_terrier.food_diet: High-quality food with a balance of proteins, fats, and carbs. Small-breed formulas are beneficial due to their fast metabolism and smaller stomachs. Portion control is important to prevent obesity.
australian_terrier.health_care: Low shedding, but the harsh, weather-resistant coat needs weekly brushing and occasional stripping/grooming to maintain texture. Needs moderate daily exercise (walks and playtime) and mental stimulation.
australian_terrier.size: Height: 23–28 cm (9–11 in); Weight: 6–7 kg (13–16 lb)
australian_terrier.common_health_issues: Patellar luxation, Legg-Calve-Perthes disease, diabetes, certain eye conditions.

basenji.nature: Intelligent, independent, curious, and fastidious (cat-like in grooming and attitude). Known as the 'barkless dog' but makes a unique yodeling sound.
basenji.food_diet: High-quality, AAFCO-approved commercial dog food. Can be fed once or twice a day. Prone to obesity, so monitor treat intake carefully. Joint supplements are often recommended due to hip dysplasia risk.
basenji.health_care: Short coat requires minimal grooming (weekly brushing). High exercise needs; requires running and play. Needs a secure yard due to high prey drive (sighthound) and tendency to escape. Requires consistent, challenging training.
basenji.size: Height: 41–43 cm (16–17 in); Weight: 10–12 kg (22–24 lb)
basenji.common_health_issues: Fanconi Syndrome (kidney disease), Progressive Retinal Atrophy (PRA), hip dysplasia, Coloboma (eye defect), Pyruvate Kinase Deficiency (PKD) anemia.

basset.nature: Gentle, patient, sweet, and somewhat lazy, but tenacious on a scent. Known for a deep, mournful bay.
basset.food_diet: High-quality food. Puppies should be fed a large-breed puppy food to slow growth rate (lowers hip dysplasia risk). Prone to obesity, so careful calorie monitoring is necessary. Feed a large-breed formula divided into two or more meals to help prevent bloat (GDV).
basset.health_care: Weekly brushing and occasional bathing. Long, drooping ears require frequent cleaning to prevent infection; a 'snood' may be used during feeding. Requires daily exercise (up to an hour) but should be monitored for joint strain. Must always be leashed outside due to strong scent drive.
basset.size: Height: Up to 38 cm (15 in); Weight: 18–29 kg (40–65 lb)
basset.common_health_issues: Obesity, gastric dilatation-volvulus (GDV/Bloat), hip and elbow dysplasia, intervertebral disc disease (IVDD), glaucoma, cherry eye, ear infections.

beagle.nature: Cheerful, friendly, curious, and determined scent hound. Great family pet but can be single-minded and prone to separation anxiety and associated barking/chewing.
beagle.food_diet: High-quality, age-appropriate food. Highly prone to **obesity**, which can worsen joint, heart, and back problems. Needs strict diet regulation, and treats should be minimal.
beagle.health_care: Low grooming needs (weekly brushing). Frequent dental care (at least three times a week) and weekly ear cleaning (floppy ears are prone to infection). Needs a secure, fenced yard and must be walked on a leash due to strong scent drive and tendency to roam. Needs daily exercise and mental stimulation.
beagle.size: Height: 33–38 cm (13–15 in); Weight: 8–14 kg (18–30 lb)
beagle.common_health_issues: Obesity, intervertebral disc disease (IVDD), glaucoma, hemophilia (bleeding disorder), epilepsy, 'Beagle Pain Syndrome' (Steroid Responsive Meningitis), dental disease.

bedlington_terrier.nature: Lively, brave, and confident, despite a lamb-like appearance. Known for its strong prey drive and tendency to dig and bark. Affectionate companion, but often strong-willed.
bedlington_terrier.food_diet: High-quality, complete, and balanced food. Needs a diet that can help manage the risk of **copper toxicosis** (consult a vet). Small, frequent meals may be beneficial due to their size.
bedlington_terrier.health_care: Low shedding, but requires weekly brushing to prevent matting. Professional grooming (clipping to achieve the classic 'lamb' look) every 6-8 weeks is typical. Needs daily exercise (minimum 1 hour) and mental stimulation, as they get bored easily. Cannot be left alone for long periods (prone to separation anxiety).
bedlington_terrier.size: Height: 41 cm (16 in); Weight: 8–10 kg (18–22 lb)
bedlington_terrier.common_health_issues: Copper toxicosis (liver disease—parents must be screened), various eye conditions (e.g., Total Retinal Dysplasia, cataracts), ear problems.

bernese_mountain_dog.nature: Gentle giant, affectionate, demonstrative, and loyal. Generally friendly toward strangers, a good watchdog, and playful.
bernese_mountain_dog.food_diet: Large-breed puppy food to slow growth rate and minimize joint risk. Adults need a high-quality, age-appropriate diet. Prone to **bloat (GDV)**, so feeding smaller, frequent meals and monitoring pre/post-exercise activity is essential. Prone to obesity.
bernese_mountain_dog.health_care: Heavy shedding and drooling. Daily brushing is required. Requires moderate daily exercise (active for a giant breed). Should have soft bedding to prevent callouses/bursitis. Does not tolerate heat well.
bernese_mountain_dog.size: Height: 58–70 cm (23–27.5 in); Weight: 32–52 kg (70–115 lb)
bernese_mountain_dog.common_health_issues: Bloat (GDV), various cancers (especially malignant histiocytosis and mast cell tumors), hip and elbow dysplasia, arthritis, subvalvular aortic stenosis (SAS—heart condition).

black-and-tan_coonhound.nature: Amiable, gentle, and playful companion. Determined tracker with a deep voice and a tendency to slobber/drool. High prey drive.
black-and-tan_coonhound.food_diet: High-quality, age-appropriate diet. Prone to obesity. As a deep-chested breed, they are highly prone to **bloat (GDV)**, so feed two or more small meals a day and limit exercise around mealtimes.
black-and-tan_coonhound.health_care: Low grooming needs; weekly brushing. Regular dental care (at least twice a week) and weekly cleaning of long, floppy ears. Needs a lot of energy and mental stimulation; must be leash-walked outside (high prey drive).
black-and-tan_coonhound.size: Height: 58–69 cm (23–27 in); Weight: 27–45 kg (60–100 lb)
black-and-tan_coonhound.common_health_issues: Bloat (GDV), hip and elbow dysplasia, cataracts, hemophilia (bleeding disorder), hypothyroidism, ear infections.

blenheim_spaniel.nature: Affectionate, elegant, gentle, and playful lapdog. Highly people-oriented and thrives on companionship.
blenheim_spaniel.food_diet: High-quality, balanced diet appropriate for a small breed. Prone to obesity, which can exacerbate heart and joint problems, so strict portion control is essential.
blenheim_spaniel.health_care: Long, silky coat requires regular brushing (daily is best) to prevent mats. Needs regular exercise (daily walks and play). Frequent veterinary heart checks are crucial due to high prevalence of **Mitral Valve Disease**.
blenheim_spaniel.size: Height: 30–33 cm (12–13 in); Weight: 5.4–8 kg (12–18 lb)
blenheim_spaniel.common_health_issues: Mitral Valve Disease (MVD—extremely common, leading cause of death), Syringomyelia (SM—neurological), episodic falling, hip dysplasia, eye conditions (e.g., cataracts).

bloodhound.nature: Gentle, affectionate, less energetic than other hounds, but tenacious on a scent. Independent and stubborn. Prone to drooling/slobbering.
bloodhound.food_diet: High-quality, age-appropriate food. Prone to obesity. Deep chest puts them at high risk for **bloat (GDV)**; feed smaller, multiple meals and use large-breed puppy food for puppies to slow growth.
bloodhound.health_care: Weekly brushing of short, dense coat. Regular bathing, paying special attention to facial/neck folds to prevent dirt buildup and infections. Must always be leashed outside (extreme scent drive). Needs plenty of daily exercise. Regular ear and eye checks.
bloodhound.size: Height: 58–69 cm (23–27 in); Weight: 34–50 kg (75–110 lb)
bloodhound.common_health_issues: Bloat (GDV), hip and elbow dysplasia, eye conditions (entropion/ectropion), ear infections, skin fold dermatitis, heart disease.

bluetick.nature: Fast, determined, and loyal scent hound. Highly athletic with a loud voice and strong instinct to roam and hunt.
bluetick.food_diet: High-quality diet appropriate for a large, high-energy working dog. Deep-chested, so highly prone to **bloat (GDV)**. Feed small, multiple meals daily and limit water/exercise around mealtimes.
bluetick.health_care: Low grooming needs; weekly brushing. Regular dental care and weekly cleaning of long, floppy ears. Requires high levels of daily exercise and mental stimulation. Must be kept in a tall, secure fence and always walked on a leash (strong prey/roaming drive).
bluetick.size: Height: 56–69 cm (22–27 in); Weight: 20–36 kg (45–80 lb)
bluetick.common_health_issues: Bloat (GDV), hip dysplasia, hypothyroidism, cataracts, cancer, Neuronal Ceroid Lipofuscinosis (NCL—neurologic disease).

border_collie.nature: Loyal, highly intelligent, energetic, and athletic. The ultimate herding dog; needs a job to do and can develop compulsive behaviors if bored.
border_collie.food_diet: High-quality, balanced diet to support high energy levels. Prone to obesity if not exercised adequately. Should be fed two meals daily. Consult a vet on joint supplements due to hip/elbow dysplasia risk.
border_collie.health_care: Moderate grooming needs; weekly brushing to manage shedding and prevent mats. Requires **significant daily exercise (1-2+ hours)** and constant mental stimulation (training, puzzle toys, herding sports) to thrive.
border_collie.size: Height: 46–56 cm (18–22 in); Weight: 14–25 kg (30–55 lb)
border_collie.common_health_issues: Collie Eye Anomaly (CEA), hip dysplasia, epilepsy, Osteochondritis Dissecans (OCD) and Progressive Retinal Atrophy (PRA).

border_terrier.nature: Affectionate, agile, and always ready for adventure. Clever, biddable, and relatively soft-tempered for a terrier, but has a high prey drive and loves to dig.
border_terrier.food_diet: Small dogs have a fast metabolism; they benefit from small-breed formulas fed in little and often portions. High-quality, complete, and balanced food is essential.
border_terrier.health_care: Undemanding grooming; weekly brushing. Hand-stripping or occasional clipping is needed to maintain the harsh, dense coat. Requires a minimum of an hour of exercise daily. Needs a very secure fence to prevent escape (high chase instinct).
border_terrier.common_health_issues: Canine Epileptoid Cramping Syndrome (CECS, or 'Spike's Disease'), heart defects, eye disorders (e.g., Progressive Retinal Atrophy), canine juvenile cataracts.

borzoi.nature: Elegant, calm, and stately. Independent and gentle with family, but reserved with strangers. Has a high prey drive (sighthound).
borzoi.food_diet: High-quality, age-appropriate food. Puppies should be fed a large-breed puppy diet to control growth rate. Prone to **bloat (GDV)**, so feed smaller, multiple meals, and limit post-meal activity.
borzoi.health_care: Long, silky coat needs regular brushing (daily is often recommended). Sighthound sensitivity to **anesthesia**—requires experienced veterinary care for surgery. Needs plenty of room to run (high speed/prey drive), so a securely fenced area is a must. Requires moderate daily exercise.
borzoi.size: Height: Males >= 71 cm (28 in), Females >= 66 cm (26 in); Weight: 25–48 kg (55–105 lb)
borzoi.common_health_issues: Bloat (GDV), sensitivity to anesthesia, osteochondritis dissecans (OCD), hip and elbow dysplasia, bone cancer (osteosarcoma).

boston_bull.nature: Intelligent, lively, and gentle. The 'American Gentleman' is affectionate, sensitive, and well-suited for apartment living.
boston_bull.food_diet: High-quality, age-appropriate diet. Prone to obesity, which exacerbates breathing and joint problems. Strict calorie control is essential. Use slow feeders to help with fast eating.
boston_bull.health_care: Low grooming needs; weekly brushing. Facial and tail-base folds must be kept clean and dry. Very sensitive to temperature extremes (**brachycephalic**—flat-faced); avoid prolonged exposure, especially heat. Requires daily walks and indoor play.
boston_bull.size: Weight: <= 11 kg (<= 25 lb) in three weight classes; Height: Not specified, size determined by weight and balance.
boston_bull.common_health_issues: Brachycephalic Airway Syndrome (breathing issues), eye problems (e.g., cataracts, glaucoma, 'cherry eye,' corneal ulcers/injuries), patellar luxation, deafness, dental disease.

bouvier_des_flandres.nature: Intelligent, friendly, fiercely loyal, and protective. Craves companionship but can be destructive if bored. Wary of strangers, low compatibility with small pets.
bouvier_des_flandres.food_diet: High-quality dog food fed in two or more small meals per day to prevent **Bloat (GDV)**. Puppies need a low-calorie, large-breed diet to control growth rate.
bouvier_des_flandres.health_care: High-maintenance grooming. Long, shaggy, rough double coat needs **daily brushing** and professional trimming. Frequent ear checks for infection. Requires **high physical and mental exercise** daily.
bouvier_des_flandres.common_health_issues: Bloat (GDV), hip and elbow dysplasia, hypothyroidism, laryngeal paralysis, various eye conditions (glaucoma, cataracts, entropion).

boxer.nature: Playful, exuberant, high-energy, and loyal. Intelligent but can be stubborn and easily bored with repetition. Bouncy nature requires early training.
boxer.food_diet: High-quality, age-appropriate food. Prone to getting overweight, so **monitor calorie consumption** and treats. Deep-chested, so feeding two or more small meals a day helps mitigate **Bloat (GDV)** risk.
boxer.health_care: Low grooming needs; once or twice weekly brushing of the short coat. **High energy**; requires ample daily exercise in a securely fenced area. Needs **daily teeth brushing** to prevent dental disease. Sensitive to heat.
boxer.size: Height: 55–64 cm (21.5–25 in); Weight: 29–36 kg (65–80 lb)
boxer.common_health_issues: Cancer (especially mast cell tumors, lymphoma), Boxer Cardiomyopathy (ARVC), Subaortic Stenosis (AS), hip dysplasia, bloat (GDV), hypothyroidism, degenerative myelopathy.

brabancon_griffon.nature: Confident, curious, charming, and affectionate. Energetic but will happily lounge with owners. Can be nervous around strangers and barks to alert.
brabancon_griffon.food_diet: High-quality dog food formulated for **small dogs**. Typically does well eating twice a day. Monitor treats carefully to prevent obesity, which can stress joints. Food should support dental health.
brabancon_griffon.health_care: Moderate daily activity (up to 30 min walk). **Daily tooth brushing** is very important due to crowded teeth and dental disease risk. Prone to **heat sensitivity** (brachycephalic). Needs careful supervision to prevent eye injuries (prominent eyes).
brabancon_griffon.size: Height: 18–20 cm (7–8 in); Weight: 3.6–5 kg (8–12 lb)
brabancon_griffon.common_health_issues: Brachycephalic syndrome, patellar luxation, hip dysplasia (often minimal signs due to size), eye issues (cataracts, PRA, injuries), dental disease.

briard.nature: Loyal, intelligent, alert, and protective. Has strong herding and guarding instincts. Needs a gentle but authoritative owner.
briard.food_diet: High-quality diet, typically two meals a day for adults. Puppies may need three meals due to higher metabolism. Treats should be minimal (under 10% of daily calories).
briard.health_care: Long, flowing double coat needs **regular (often daily) thorough brushing** to prevent mats. Monitor for skin infections and debris trapped in the coat. Requires plenty of daily exercise and mental stimulation. Sensitive to heat.
briard.size: Height: 58–69 cm (23–27 in); Weight: 32–45 kg (70–100 lb) - AKC standard: males 22-27 kg; females 15-22 kg.
briard.common_health_issues: Hip dysplasia, congenital stationary night blindness, hereditary cataracts, hypothyroidism, corneal dystrophy, bloat (GDV).

brittany_spaniel.nature: Bright, energetic, athletic, and fun-loving. Excellent hunting companion. Very sensitive breed that responds best to positive reinforcement.
brittany_spaniel.food_diet: High-quality, balanced diet to support their high energy and athleticism. Obesity is a risk if under-exercised, which can worsen joint issues. **Annual thyroid level checks** are recommended, as hypothyroidism can lead to obesity.
brittany_spaniel.health_care: Moderate grooming needs. Requires **high daily exercise** and mental stimulation (field work, agility). Prone to skin issues and joint problems, so a proper diet and exercise routine are key. Minimize sun exposure (due to DLE risk).
brittany_spaniel.common_health_issues: Hip dysplasia, elbow dysplasia, hypothyroidism, epilepsy, cataracts, Discoid Lupus Erythematosus (DLE—skin disease).

bull_mastiff.nature: Fiercely loyal and protective guardian, yet gentle and patient with family. Naturally wary of strangers. Quiet breed, barks mainly to alert.
bull_mastiff.food_diet: High-quality, protein-rich diet to maintain muscle mass. Adult Bullmastiffs eat significantly (2–3 cups of dry food twice a day). **High risk of Bloat (GDV)**; feed multiple small meals. Puppies must be on a large-breed puppy formula with controlled calories for slow growth.
bull_mastiff.health_care: Low to moderate shedding; weekly brushing. Needs about an **hour of moderate daily exercise**; does not require excessive running. Prone to drooling. Check for joint support ingredients (glucosamine/chondroitin) in food or supplements.
bull_mastiff.size: Height: 61–69 cm (24–27 in); Weight: 45–59 kg (100–130 lb)
bull_mastiff.common_health_issues: Bloat (GDV), hip and elbow dysplasia, various cancers (lymphoma, mast cell tumors), entropion/ectropion (eyelid issues), Subaortic Stenosis (SAS—heart condition).

cairn.nature: Small, alert, and curious digger. Hardy, friendly, and enjoys playing with children. Famous as 'Toto' in *The Wizard of Oz*.
cairn.food_diet: High-quality, age-appropriate diet. Prone to obesity, which can worsen joint and heart problems; strict portion control is necessary. Feed two meals daily.
cairn.health_care: Low grooming needs; weekly brushing. Needs **daily walks** and playtime. High prey drive means a leash and a secured fence are a must. Monitor for dental disease. Genetically prone to some serious diseases.
cairn.size: Height: 23–33 cm (9–13 in); Weight: 6–7.5 kg (13–16 lb)
cairn.common_health_issues: Portosystemic Shunt (PSS—liver disorder), Patellar luxation, craniomandibular osteopathy ('Scottie Jaw'), microphthalmia (small eyes), Globoid Cell Leukodystrophy (neurological), Hemolytic Anemia (blood disorder), dental disease.

cardigan.nature: Affectionate, active companion, intelligent, and fiercely loyal. Natural herder; may try to 'herd' family members by nipping heels.
cardigan.food_diet: High-quality, age-appropriate food. **Highly prone to obesity** (due to short stature and love of food); strictly monitor calorie intake and treats. Feed two meals daily.
cardigan.health_care: Sheds heavily twice a year, requiring **daily brushing** during these times; weekly brushing otherwise. Needs daily walks and activity. Due to a long back and short legs, prevent jumping off furniture and support the back when picking up to prevent **Intervertebral Disc Disease (IVDD)**.
cardigan.size: Height: 25–33 cm (10–13 in); Weight: 11–17 kg (25–38 lb)
cardigan.common_health_issues: Intervertebral Disc Disease (IVDD—spinal disk disease), hip and elbow dysplasia, Progressive Retinal Atrophy (PRA), Degenerative Myelopathy (DM), urinary bladder stones.

chesapeake_bay_retriever.nature: Alert, energetic, loyal, and brave. More independent and aloof than other retrievers. Built for cold-water hunting; strong working drive.
chesapeake_bay_retriever.food_diet: High-quality food formulated for large breeds. Puppies should be on a large-breed puppy diet to control growth rate (reducing hip dysplasia risk). Prone to being overweight; **monitor food and treat intake closely**.
chesapeake_bay_retriever.health_care: Short, thick coat with natural oils needs **weekly brushing**. Avoid bathing before cold-weather hunting. Needs **plenty of daily vigorous exercise** and mental challenges (swimming, retrieving, dog sports). Early socialization and training are key.
chesapeake_bay_retriever.size: Height: 53–66 cm (21–26 in); Weight: 22–39 kg (55–85 lb)
chesapeake_bay_retriever.common_health_issues: Hip and elbow dysplasia, Exercise-Induced Collapse (EIC), Degenerative Myelopathy (DM), Chondrodystrophy and IVDD risk, Progressive Retinal Atrophy (PRA).

chihuahua.nature: Spunky, protective, charming, and loving. Can be intensely attached to one person and is highly vocal/alert (prone to barking).
chihuahua.food_diet: High-quality food formulated for **small/toy breeds**. Prone to obesity, which can shorten lifespan; monitor portions carefully. Puppies may need to eat more frequently to prevent hypoglycemia. Food should support dental health.
chihuahua.health_care: Grooming depends on coat length: Long coat needs daily brushing; short coat needs weekly brushing. Needs frequent mental and physical stimulation (daily walks/playtime). **Daily tooth brushing** is vital due to high dental disease risk. Monitor for eye injuries (prominent eyes).
chihuahua.size: Weight: <= 2.7 kg (<= 6 lb); Height: Not specified, but very small.
chihuahua.common_health_issues: Dental disease, heart disease (Mitral Valve Disease), luxating patella, collapsed trachea, hypoglycemia, open fontanel (soft spot on head), Hydrocephalus.

chow.nature: Extremely independent, aloof, and stubborn. Loyal to family but reserved with strangers. Not playful as an adult. Has a distinctive blue-black/purplish tongue.
chow.food_diet: High-quality diet. Puppies should be on a **large-breed puppy diet** to slow growth rate. Needs weight monitoring. Feed two small meals a day. Not a picky eater.
chow.health_care: Rough coat needs **daily or every-other-day thorough brushing** to prevent severe matting. Smooth coat needs twice weekly brushing. Requires at least an **hour of non-strenuous exercise** daily (leisurely walk). Not built for jogging. Sensitive to heat.
chow.size: Height: 43–51 cm (17–20 in); Weight: 20–32 kg (45–70 lb)
chow.common_health_issues: Hip and elbow dysplasia, entropion (eyelids rolling inward), patellar luxation, thyroid and autoimmune issues, distichiasis (extra eyelashes).

clumber.nature: Gentle, calm, steady, and sensible. Needs plenty of training. Likes to carry objects in its mouth. Prone to drooling and shedding heavily.
clumber.food_diet: High-quality, age-appropriate food. Prone to weight gain; strict portion control is necessary. Requires a moderate energy diet. Feed two measured meals daily.
clumber.health_care: Heavy shedding; needs **frequent brushing** (4/5 grooming score) and occasional clipping/trimming. Needs **gentle daily walks** and regular training. Its excellent nose means a strong recall is vital. Needs owners who can cope with drool and mud.
clumber.size: Height: 43–51 cm (17–20 in); Weight: 25–39 kg (55–85 lb)
clumber.common_health_issues: Hip and elbow dysplasia, Exercise-Induced Collapse (EIC), entropion/ectropion (eyelid issues), dry eye (Keratoconjunctivitis sicca), Pyruvate Kinase Deficiency (PKD).

cocker_spaniel.origin: United States (American Cocker) / United Kingdom (English Cocker)
cocker_spaniel.nature: Merry, friendly, sweet-tempered, and affectionate. Loves being close to people and wants to please its owner.
cocker_spaniel.food_diet: High-quality, age-appropriate food. Easily becomes overweight if overfed, which stresses their joints. Limit treats to less than 10% of daily diet.
cocker_spaniel.health_care: Lush coat requires **daily brushing** and routine professional grooming to prevent mats (a cause of skin infections/Pyoderma). Floppy ears need **regular cleaning** (especially after swimming/baths) due to high risk of ear infections. Requires moderate daily exercise (walks and playtime).
cocker_spaniel.size: Height: 35–38 cm (13.5–15 in); Weight: 9–14 kg (20–30 lb)
cocker_spaniel.common_health_issues: Ear infections, Pyoderma (skin infections), hip dysplasia, various eye conditions (glaucoma, cataracts, PRA), Von Willebrand disease (vWD—bleeding disorder).

collie.nature: Elegant, loyal, intelligent, and sensitive. Good-natured family companions. May try to 'herd' people. Can be suspicious of strangers.
collie.food_diet: High-quality, complete, and balanced food. Prone to obesity if under-exercised. Two meals a day is typical. Sensitive to certain medications (**MDR1 gene**), which requires veterinary caution.
collie.health_care: Rough coat needs **thorough weekly brushing** (daily during shedding seasons). Smooth coat needs brushing every 1-2 weeks. Needs daily exercise. Sensitive to heat; requires shade and fresh water in warm weather. Owners must test for the **MDR1 gene** (drug sensitivity).
collie.size: Height: 56–66 cm (22–26 in); Weight: 23–34 kg (50–75 lb)
collie.common_health_issues: MDR1 drug sensitivity (fatal reaction to certain common drugs), Collie Eye Anomaly (CEA), Progressive Retinal Atrophy (PRA), hip dysplasia, bloat (GDV).

curly-coated_retriever.nature: Proud, smart, and a devoted companion. Oldest of the retriever breeds. Excels at retrieving and swimming; high energy.
curly-coated_retriever.food_diet: High-quality, age-appropriate food. Deep-chested breed prone to **Bloat (GDV)**; feed multiple smaller meals a day and restrict exercise around mealtimes. Prone to obesity.
curly-coated_retriever.health_care: Easy-care, water-resistant coat needs only **occasional trimming and periodic bathing** (do not over-brush the curls). Needs high daily activity (swimming, flyball, agility). Early socialization is needed to prevent shyness/nervousness. Regular dental care.
curly-coated_retriever.size: Height: 58–69 cm (23–27 in); Weight: 25–41 kg (55–90 lb)
curly-coated_retriever.common_health_issues: Bloat (GDV), hip and elbow dysplasia, various eye conditions (cataracts, PRA, entropion), Glycogen Storage Disease (GSD).

dandie_dinmont.nature: Small, dignified, independent, and affectionate. Not a picky eater. Has a long body (prone to back issues).
dandie_dinmont.food_diet: High-quality dog food formulated for **small dogs**. Typically does well eating twice a day (up to four times for puppies to prevent hypoglycemia). **Prone to easy weight gain**, which can cause back/joint issues; careful portion control is vital.
dandie_dinmont.health_care: Wiry coat needs regular brushing and stripping to maintain. Needs daily exercise and mental stimulation (barn hunt, scent work). **Obesity prevention** is critical for their long backs. Late-onset eye checks are important.
dandie_dinmont.size: Height: 20–28 cm (8–11 in); Weight: 8–11 kg (18–24 lb)
dandie_dinmont.common_health_issues: Glaucoma (late onset), Intervertebral Disc Disease (IVDD—spinal issues exacerbated by weight), Cushing's Disease, Epilepsy, Lymphoma.

dhole.nature: Highly social, intelligent, and agile **wild dog** living in large clans. Diurnal pack hunter with a high prey drive. Highly vocal (whistles, howls, screams).
dhole.food_diet: Wild diet consists primarily of **large and medium-sized ungulates** (deer, wild pigs) hunted in packs. Known for extremely efficient and fast prey consumption to compete with other predators (tigers, leopards).
dhole.health_care: Managed in captivity. In the wild, populations are decreasing and the species is listed as **Endangered**. Subject to various wild diseases and parasites, and often competes with domestic dogs for resources and disease exposure.
dhole.group: Wild Canid (Not a domestic breed group)
dhole.size: Height: 42–50 cm (17–20 in); Weight: 10–21 kg (22–46 lb)
dhole.common_health_issues: Vulnerable to diseases from domestic dogs (Canine Distemper Virus, rabies), habitat loss, and persecution by humans.

dingo.nature: **Wild dog** (Australia's largest terrestrial carnivore). Highly resourceful and independent. Hunts alone or in cooperative packs; mostly nocturnal/crepuscular. Communicates via howls/yelps, rarely barks.
dingo.food_diet: Opportunistic hunter/scavenger. Bulk diet is **meat** (kangaroos, wallabies, feral pigs, rabbits). Also eats small mammals, birds, reptiles, fish, and occasionally plants/fruits. Needs a highly varied and protein-rich diet.
dingo.health_care: Managed in captivity. In the wild, they regulate feral predator numbers and keep native herbivore populations in check. Wild animals are subject to environmental pressures, parasites, and competition.
dingo.group: Wild Canid (Not a domestic breed group)
dingo.size: Height: 52–60 cm (20–24 in); Weight: 13–20 kg (29–44 lb)
dingo.common_health_issues: Parasitic infections, heat stress, and persecution by humans (baiting, culling) in the wild. Prone to hybridisation with domestic dogs.

doberman.nature: Sleek, intelligent, alert, and fiercely loyal family protector. Highly energetic and requires constant mental and physical activity. Easy to train but can be reserved/timid if not socialized.
doberman.food_diet: High-quality, age-appropriate, protein-rich diet. Deep-chested breed at **high risk for Bloat (GDV)**; feed two or more small meals a day and restrict exercise around mealtimes.
doberman.health_care: Short, smooth coat requires minimal grooming. Requires a **significant amount of vigorous daily exercise** (running, agility) and mental challenge. Early and consistent socialization and training are mandatory for a well-rounded temperament. **Annual heart monitoring** (Holter test) is advised.
doberman.size: Height: 61–71 cm (24–28 in); Weight: 27–40 kg (60–88 lb)
doberman.common_health_issues: Dilated Cardiomyopathy (DCM—enlarged heart), Bloat (GDV), Wobbler Syndrome (spinal disease), Von Willebrand disease (vWD—clotting disorder), hip dysplasia, hypothyroidism, Narcolepsy.

english_foxhound.nature: Affectionate, companionable, and highly energetic. Pack-oriented, friendly with other dogs, but has a strong prey drive. Very vocal (high tendency to bark/bay).
english_foxhound.food_diet: High-quality, balanced diet, fed as two measured meals per day. Deep-chested; prone to **Bloat (GDV)**, so monitor meal size and activity around feeding.
english_foxhound.health_care: Low grooming needs; weekly brushing of the short coat. Weekly ear checks/cleaning. **Extremely high exercise needs**; often too energetic and vocal for apartment living. Requires a secure yard and daily vigorous activity.
english_foxhound.size: Height: approx 61 cm (24 in); Weight: 27–34 kg (60–75 lb)
english_foxhound.common_health_issues: Bloat (GDV), ear infections, hip dysplasia (generally a healthy breed).

english_setter.nature: Gentle, friendly, and mild-mannered. Sensitive and affectionate, often playful. Mellows with age but needs constant interaction; dislikes being left alone.
english_setter.food_diet: High-quality, balanced diet. Prone to obesity if under-exercised. Feed measured portions, typically twice daily. Care must be taken with puppy growth rates to protect immature bones.
english_setter.health_care: High grooming needs; long coat needs **weekly brushing** (daily is ideal) to prevent mats and tangles. Needs **plenty of daily exercise** (long brisk walks, jogging). Prone to roaming; needs a secure area. Long flews can drip water after drinking.
english_setter.size: Height: 64–69 cm (25–27 in); Weight: 20–36 kg (45–80 lb)
english_setter.common_health_issues: Hip and elbow dysplasia, hereditary deafness, hypothyroidism, bloat (GDV), progressive retinal atrophy (PRA).

english_springer.nature: Friendly, affectionate, and cheerful. Highly intelligent and eager to please. Energetic and curious; loves outdoor activities and is great with kids/pets.
english_springer.food_diet: High-quality food rich in protein and healthy fats to support high energy levels. Feed measured portions twice daily. Weight must be monitored closely to protect joints.
english_springer.health_care: Moderate grooming needs; the medium, feathered coat needs **regular brushing** and occasional trimming. Long, floppy ears need **regular cleaning** to prevent ear infections. Requires **at least 1-2 hours of daily vigorous exercise** (swimming, fetch, agility).
english_springer.size: Height: 46–56 cm (18–22 in); Weight: 18–25 kg (40–55 lb)
english_springer.common_health_issues: Hip and elbow dysplasia, ear infections, eye conditions (PRA, Retinal Dysplasia), Fucosidosis (neurological).

entlebucher.nature: Compact, energetic, and highly loyal. Versatile working breed (herding). Requires **constant companionship** and vigorous mental/physical activity; dislikes being alone.
entlebucher.food_diet: Balanced diet fed **at least twice daily**. Maintaining an **ideal body condition score** is crucial due to their robust frame, which can stress joints if overweight.
entlebucher.health_care: Short coat has **low grooming needs**. Requires a minimum of **two hours of vigorous daily exercise** (running, herding work) plus mental challenges. Better suited for rural homes with large, secure gardens. Needs a firm but fair owner.
entlebucher.common_health_issues: Progressive Retinal Atrophy (PRA), hip dysplasia, Hemolytic Anemia, patellar luxation.

eskimo_dog.nature: Fluffy, friendly, spunky, and highly intelligent. Needs strong bonds with owners. Highly vocal and prone to separation anxiety/destructive behavior if neglected.
eskimo_dog.food_diet: High-quality, age-appropriate diet. Prone to obesity. Careful monitoring of treats is important. Food should support joint and dental health.
eskimo_dog.health_care: **Heavy shedder**; requires **thorough brushing at least three times per week** to prevent matting. Needs vigorous exercise several times a day and frequent mental challenges. Barking can be a problem if needs are not met.
eskimo_dog.size: Height: 38–48 cm (15–19 in); Weight: 11–16 kg (25–35 lb) - Standard size.
eskimo_dog.common_health_issues: Hip dysplasia, Legg-Calve-Perthes Disease (LCP), Progressive Retinal Atrophy (PRA), cataracts, dental disease, pyoderma (skin infections), epilepsy.

flat-coated_retriever.nature: Joyful, optimistic, intelligent, and famously retains a 'puppy-like enthusiasm' (the 'Peter Pan of Dogs'). Loves people and water; high-energy.
flat-coated_retriever.food_diet: High-quality, age-appropriate diet. Deep-chested; prone to **Bloat (GDV)**, so feed multiple smaller meals and restrict exercise around mealtimes. Prone to obesity; monitor calories closely.
flat-coated_retriever.health_care: Medium-length, dense coat needs **weekly brushing**. Requires **significant daily vigorous exercise** (running, swimming, fetch). Excels at dog sports (agility, dock diving) and needs an active owner. Requires weekly dental and ear care.
flat-coated_retriever.size: Height: 58–64 cm (23–25 in); Weight: 25–36 kg (55–80 lb)
flat-coated_retriever.common_health_issues: Hip and elbow dysplasia, various cancers (histiocytic sarcoma, hemangiosarcoma), bloat (GDV), Glaucoma, patellar luxation.

french_bulldog.nature: Joyful, clownish, affectionate, and relatively energetic, but enjoys relaxing. Stubborn during training. Known for iconic bat ears.
french_bulldog.food_diet: High-quality, balanced diet. Prone to **obesity**, which severely exacerbates breathing issues; monitor portions strictly. Use slow-feeder bowls to prevent gulping air.
french_bulldog.health_care: Low grooming needs. **Extreme care to prevent overheating** (brachycephalic—short-nosed); must stay in moderate temperatures. Needs daily short walks/play. Requires veterinary inspection for **BOAS** (Brachycephalic Obstructive Airway Syndrome). Anesthesia sensitive.
french_bulldog.size: Height: 28–33 cm (11–13 in); Weight: <= 13 kg (<= 28 lb)
french_bulldog.common_health_issues: BOAS, Hip Dysplasia, Intervertebral Disc Disease (IVDD), hemivertebrae (spinal deformity), luxating patella, eye issues.

german_shepherd.nature: Loyal, courageous, confident, and highly intelligent. Needs a job or task. Can be wary and distrustful of strangers; prone to being overprotective.
german_shepherd.food_diet: High-quality, age-appropriate diet. Deep-chested breed at **high risk for Bloat (GDV)**; feed two or more small meals a day. Puppies need large-breed puppy food to manage growth rate and minimize joint issues. Prone to obesity.
german_shepherd.health_care: Heavy shedder; needs **weekly thorough brushing** (daily during bi-annual 'blowouts'). Requires **significant daily vigorous exercise** and mental activity (agility, training) to prevent boredom/destructive behavior. Frequent veterinary joint checks (hip/elbows).
german_shepherd.size: Height: 56–66 cm (22–26 in); Weight: 22–40 kg (50–88 lb)
german_shepherd.common_health_issues: Hip and elbow dysplasia, bloat (GDV), Degenerative Myelopathy (DM), Pancreatic enzyme insufficiency (PEI), perianal fistulas.

german_short-haired_pointer.nature: Versatile, affectionate, intelligent, and highly energetic hunter. Thrives on activity and strong bonds with family.
german_short-haired_pointer.food_diet: Diet with a **higher fat/protein ratio** ('sport' or 'performance') to support active lifestyle. Deep-chested; prone to **Bloat (GDV)**. Feed multiple small meals daily, use slow feeders, and restrict exercise 1 hour before/after eating. Avoid elevated food bowls.
german_short-haired_pointer.health_care: Short coat has low grooming needs (weekly brushing). Requires **intense, daily vigorous exercise** (running, hunting, long walks) and mental challenges. Needs early and consistent training/socialization. Frequent heart checks for young dogs.
german_short-haired_pointer.size: Height: 58–64 cm (23–25 in); Weight: 20–32 kg (45–70 lb)
german_short-haired_pointer.common_health_issues: Hip and elbow dysplasia, bloat (GDV), Subaortic Stenosis (SAS—heart condition), Progressive Retinal Atrophy (PRA), Von Willebrand disease (vWD).

giant_schnauzer.nature: Powerful, loyal, and more serious than other Schnauzer types. Highly intelligent and needs a confident leader. Wary of strangers; used as a protection dog.
giant_schnauzer.food_diet: High-quality, balanced diet. Prone to bloat (GDV); feed multiple small meals a day. Joint-supporting supplements are often recommended.
giant_schnauzer.health_care: High maintenance grooming. Wiry coat needs **frequent brushing** and professional stripping/clipping. The beard must be kept clean. Needs **lots of physical and mental exercise**.
giant_schnauzer.common_health_issues: Hip dysplasia, bloat (GDV), various cancers (osteosarcoma), hypothyroidism, Progressive Retinal Atrophy (PRA), autoimmune disorders.

golden_retriever.nature: Friendly, intelligent, devoted, and gentle. High affection level and loves to be around family. Energetic and highly trainable. **Food-obsessed**.
golden_retriever.food_diet: High-quality, low-calorie diet. Puppies need a **low-calorie large-breed puppy diet** for slow growth. Adults need measured portions, typically two meals a day. **Strict weight monitoring** is crucial to prevent obesity.
golden_retriever.health_care: High shedding (heavily in spring/fall); needs **daily brushing**. Requires **significant daily exercise** (1-2 hours) and training/mental work. Frequent vet checks for cancer and heart conditions.
golden_retriever.size: Height: 55–61 cm (21.5–24 in); Weight: 25–34 kg (55–75 lb)
golden_retriever.common_health_issues: Various cancers (Hemangiosarcoma, Lymphoma), Hip and Elbow Dysplasia, Subvalvular Aortic Stenosis (SAS—heart condition), Hypothyroidism.

gordon_setter.nature: Intelligent, loyal, and energetic gundog. Happy-go-lucky, friendly, and excels at hunting. Retains a puppy-like exuberance into adulthood.
gordon_setter.food_diet: High-quality, balanced diet. Deep-chested; prone to **Bloat (GDV)**. Feed **multiple smaller meals** daily and **restrict exercise before/after meals**.
gordon_setter.health_care: Long, feathered coat needs **weekly brushing** to prevent tangles/matting. Ears need regular cleaning. Requires a **high level of daily physical and mental exercise**.
gordon_setter.size: Height: 58–69 cm (23–27 in); Weight: 20–36 kg (45–80 lb)
gordon_setter.common_health_issues: Bloat (GDV), Hip Dysplasia, Hypothyroidism, Progressive Retinal Atrophy (PRA), Canine Leukocyte Adhesion Deficiency (CLAD), Epilepsy.

great_dane.nature: Gentle giant, kind-hearted, and affectionate with family. Low heat tolerance. Shortest lifespan of large breeds.
great_dane.food_diet: Requires a **large-breed diet**. Puppies need low-calorie food designed for large breeds for **slow growth rate**. Adults must be fed **smaller, multiple meals** (2-3 times) daily to minimize the **Bloat (GDV)** risk.
great_dane.health_care: Short coat has low grooming needs (weekly brushing). Needs daily short walks/play (30-60 min for adults). **Frequent cardiac and bloat checks are critical**.
great_dane.size: Height: 71–81 cm (28–32 in); Weight: 45–90 kg (100–200 lb)
great_dane.common_health_issues: Bloat (GDV) – highest risk, Dilated Cardiomyopathy (DCM—heart), Wobbler Syndrome (cervical spine issues), Hip Dysplasia, Bone Cancer (Osteosarcoma).

great_pyrenees.nature: Calm, patient, and protective livestock guardian. Reserved and gentle. Independent and stubborn (due to working heritage).
great_pyrenees.food_diet: High-quality diet formulated for large or giant breeds. Prone to **Bloat (GDV)**; feed multiple, smaller meals a day. **Prone to obesity**, so strict portion control is necessary.
great_pyrenees.health_care: Thick double coat needs **weekly brushing** (daily during heavy shedding). Needs moderate daily exercise. Requires socialization and training to manage protective instincts. Prone to developing callouses/hygromas; needs soft bedding.
great_pyrenees.size: Height: 63–81 cm (25–32 in); Weight: 45–59 kg (100–130 lb)
great_pyrenees.common_health_issues: Hip and elbow dysplasia, bloat (GDV), Addison's disease (adrenal disorder), Bone Cancer (Osteosarcoma), Degenerative Myelopathy (DM).

greater_swiss_mountain_dog.nature: Strong, friendly, loyal, and dependable. Patient with kids and good watchdogs. Can be boisterous, especially when young. Does not tolerate heat well.
greater_swiss_mountain_dog.food_diet: Quality, nutritionally balanced diet. Deep-chested; high risk for **Bloat (GDV)**, so feed two measured meals per day. Puppies need a controlled large-breed formula to prevent orthopedic problems.
greater_swiss_mountain_dog.health_care: Short, smooth coat has low grooming needs. Requires a **medium level of daily exercise** and playtime. Likes to be included in family activities. Early training is needed to manage boisterousness and occasional stubbornness.
greater_swiss_mountain_dog.common_health_issues: Bloat (GDV), hip and elbow dysplasia, OCD, splenic torsion, urinary incontinence, epilepsy.

groenendael.nature: Elegant, intelligent, and highly protective. Requires almost constant attention. Strong working instinct; thrives when mentally and physically active. Naturally wary of strangers.
groenendael.food_diet: High-quality, age-appropriate diet to support high energy levels. Prone to obesity if not active enough. Feed two measured meals per day.
groenendael.health_care: Long coat sheds heavily bi-annually; needs **weekly thorough brushing** (daily during shedding). Requires a **significant amount of vigorous daily exercise** and constant mental challenge (agility, training). Early socialization is vital.
groenendael.size: Height: 56–66 cm (22–26 in); Weight: 20–30 kg (45–65 lb)
groenendael.common_health_issues: Epilepsy, cataracts, various cancers (Lymphoma), hip and elbow dysplasia, bloat (GDV), Progressive Retinal Atrophy (PRA).

ibizan_hound.nature: Athletic and graceful, with a noble and reserved demeanor. Quiet indoors, but intensely energetic outdoors (high prey/chase drive).
ibizan_hound.food_diet: High-quality, balanced diet. Feed two meals daily. Sighthound sensitivity to anesthesia means diet and overall health should be monitored carefully.
ibizan_hound.health_care: Low grooming needs (short coat needs minimal care). Needs **daily vigorous running** in a safe, securely fenced area (can jump very high and chase prey). Must be leash walked/fenced.
ibizan_hound.size: Height: 60–74 cm (23.5–29 in); Weight: 20–25 kg (45–55 lb)
ibizan_hound.common_health_issues: Sighthound anesthesia sensitivity, deafness, Progressive Retinal Atrophy (PRA), Axonal Dystrophy (neurological).

irish_setter.nature: Elegant, playful, affectionate, and high-energy. Happy-go-lucky and remains puppy-like into adulthood. Mischievous and sociable.
irish_setter.food_diet: High-quality, balanced diet. Deep-chested; prone to **Bloat (GDV)**. Feed **multiple smaller meals** daily and **restrict exercise before/after meals**. Avoid high-protein/calcium puppy foods as they can cause **Hypertrophic Osteodystrophy (HOD)**.
irish_setter.health_care: Long, flowing red coat needs **weekly brushing** (daily is often recommended) to prevent matting. Requires a **high level of daily physical and mental exercise** (2+ hours). Frequent checks for joint health. DNA testing for **CLAD** is advised.
irish_setter.size: Height: 64–69 cm (25–27 in); Weight: 26–32 kg (57–70 lb)
irish_setter.common_health_issues: Bloat (GDV), Hip Dysplasia, Hypertrophic Osteodystrophy (HOD—puppies), Canine Leukocyte Adhesion Deficiency (CLAD), Progressive Retinal Atrophy (PRA), Epilepsy, Hypothyroidism.

irish_terrier.nature: Bold, spirited, even-tempered, and affectionate. One of the oldest terrier breeds. High-energy and resilient.
irish_terrier.food_diet: High-quality dry dog food or a vet-regulated homemade diet appropriate for age and high energy level. Limit treats and ensure fresh water is available at all times.
irish_terrier.health_care: Low shedding/drooling; requires **monthly coat maintenance** (hand-stripping is preferred over trimming to maintain coat texture). Needs **weekly nail trims, teeth brushing, and ear cleaning**. Requires **high daily energy release** through exercise and play. Check for environmental allergies (common in terriers).
irish_terrier.size: Height: 46 cm (18 in); Weight: 11–12 kg (25–27 lb)
irish_terrier.common_health_issues: Bladder stones, sensitivity to environmental allergies, hyperkeratosis (digital, on the paws).

irish_water_spaniel.nature: Versatile gundog, energetic, and fun-loving. Aloof with strangers but even-tempered and confident once mature. Sensitive nature as a puppy/young dog.
irish_water_spaniel.food_diet: Balanced diet with all main nutrients. Should be fed **at least twice daily**. Regular body condition scores are important to prevent obesity.
irish_water_spaniel.health_care: Water-proof, weather-proof coat needs **grooming every other day** to prevent mats. Requires **two or more hours of vigorous daily exercise** (long walks, swimming, field work). Rural/quiet suburban homes are best due to high energy and need for space. Weekly ear checks are important.
irish_water_spaniel.size: Height: 51–58 cm (20–23 in); Weight: 20–30 kg (45–66 lb)
irish_water_spaniel.common_health_issues: Hip dysplasia, various hereditary eye disorders (cataracts, Progressive Retinal Atrophy), hypothyroidism, distichiasis (extra eyelashes).

irish_wolfhound.nature: The tallest breed; gentle, quiet, and easygoing, despite imposing size. Very affectionate with family. Low barking tendency. Strong prey drive.
irish_wolfhound.food_diet: Requires a **large-breed diet**. Puppies need low-calorie food designed for large/giant breeds for **slow growth rate** (critical for skeletal health). Adults must be fed **smaller, multiple meals** daily to minimize **Bloat (GDV)** risk. Expect a hefty food budget.
irish_wolfhound.health_care: **Shortest lifespan of all breeds** (6-8 years). Wiry coat needs weekly brushing. Needs lots of space and moderate daily exercise; avoid over-exercising puppies. **Frequent cardiac and bloat checks are critical**. Must be leashed/fenced (strong prey drive).
irish_wolfhound.size: Height: Males >= 81 cm (32 in), Females >= 76 cm (30 in); Weight: Males >= 54.5 kg (120 lb), Females >= 47.5 kg (105 lb)
irish_wolfhound.common_health_issues: Bloat (GDV) – high risk, Heart Disease (IWCM, Atrial Fibrillation), Bone Cancer (Osteosarcoma), Liver Shunt, Hip and Elbow Dysplasia, Pneumonia.

italian_greyhound.nature: Affectionate, playful, and companionable. Slender and delicate. Can be sensitive and stubborn about training. Does not tolerate cold weather well.
italian_greyhound.food_diet: High-quality, nutritionally balanced diet, fed as two measured meals per day. Monitor treats closely; even minor weight gain can stress their slender legs and joints. Food should support dental health.
italian_greyhound.health_care: Simple grooming; short, smooth coat needs minimal brushing. Needs daily exercise and mental stimulation. **Highly prone to broken legs**; requires a lot of care, especially when young. **Daily tooth brushing** is crucial due to high dental disease risk. Needs sweaters in cold weather.
italian_greyhound.size: Height: 33–38 cm (13–15 in); Weight: 3–6.5 kg (7–14 lb)
italian_greyhound.common_health_issues: Leg breaks, dental disease, patellar luxation, Legg-Calve-Perthes disease (LCPD), hypothyroidism, cataracts, sighthound anesthesia sensitivity.

japanese_spaniel.nature: Charming, playful, and aristocratic. Highly intelligent and affectionate. Can 'chin spin' when excited. Needs gentle handling.
japanese_spaniel.food_diet: Small dogs; eat little (under 1 cup dry food/day). High-quality, AAFCO-certified, well-balanced food is essential. Consult a vet for specific amounts based on size and low-activity needs.
japanese_spaniel.health_care: Silky, single coat sheds moderately; needs **daily brushing** to keep it tangle-free. **Brachycephalic** (flat-faced) – prone to overheating and breathing issues. Prone to eye injuries due to prominent eyes. Needs minimal daily exercise.
japanese_spaniel.size: Height: 20–28 cm (8–11 in); Weight: 2–3 kg (4–7 lb)
japanese_spaniel.common_health_issues: Patellar luxation, cataracts, epilepsy, Brachycephalic Airway Syndrome, eye injuries, **Tay-Sachs disease** (fatal neurodegenerative illness - genetic testing advised).

keeshond.nature: Cheerful, alert, and very vocal. Known as the 'Smiling Dutchman' or 'Dutch Barge Dog'. Excellent watchdog. Friendly and companionable; very keen to alert owners to trouble.
keeshond.food_diet: Balanced diet fed **at least twice daily**. Regular body condition scores are important, as they can be prone to weight gain under their thick coat.
keeshond.health_care: Dense double coat needs **daily brushing** to prevent matting. Requires an **hour of daily exercise** plus mental stimulation (puzzles, training). Very vocal, so training for unwanted barking is necessary. Tolerates all weather conditions well.
keeshond.size: Height: 43–46 cm (17–18 in); Weight: 16–18 kg (35–40 lb)
keeshond.common_health_issues: Hip and elbow dysplasia, patellar luxation, primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT—genetic testing available), Progressive Retinal Atrophy (PRA), epilepsy, skin and coat problems.

australian_kelpie.nature: Hardworking, extremely intelligent, tireless, and independent herding dog. Requires constant occupation and can develop behavioral issues if bored.
australian_kelpie.food_diet: High-quality, complete, and balanced food. Diet should be high-performance (higher calorie) if working/exercising heavily (1-2+ hours/day), or standard adult formula if a pet with moderate exercise. Prone to obesity if under-exercised, so monitor weight.
australian_kelpie.health_care: Low grooming needs; weekly brushing (sheds heavily during 'blowout' seasons). Requires 1-2+ hours of heavy daily exercise (running, swimming) plus mental stimulation (agility, scent work, training) to prevent compulsive behaviors and destructiveness. Excellent heat tolerance.
australian_kelpie.size: Height: 40–51 cm (15.5–20 in); Weight: 11–22 kg (24–48 lb)
australian_kelpie.common_health_issues: Hip dysplasia, cerebellar abiotrophy (neurological condition), Progressive Retinal Atrophy (PRA), dental issues (generally very hardy breed).

kerry_blue_terrier.nature: Intelligent, independent, and playful. Loves family and is a good guard dog (tends to bark). Has a strong hunting instinct; best as the only pet.
kerry_blue_terrier.food_diet: High-quality, balanced diet to meet energy requirements. Needs lean protein to support their athletic build. Limit treats. Food should support their skin health (prone to allergies).
kerry_blue_terrier.health_care: The unique blue-gray coat needs **thorough weekly brushing**. Professional grooming (trimming/clipping) is required. Requires **plenty of daily exercise** (long walk plus playtime/dog sports) to prevent digging/misbehavior. Needs early socialization due to suspicion of strange dogs.
kerry_blue_terrier.size: Height: 44–51 cm (17.5–20 in); Weight: 15–18 kg (33–40 lb)
kerry_blue_terrier.common_health_issues: Cataracts, Persistent Pupillary Membranes (PPM—eye defect), hip dysplasia, foot/nail problems, various orthopedic issues, skin allergies.

komondor.nature: Livestock guardian with a distinctive corded coat. Steady, fearless, and independent. Affectionate and gentle with family, but reserved/suspicious of strangers. High tendency to bark at passersby.
komondor.food_diet: High-quality diet with lean proteins. Large/Giant breed food. Prone to **Bloat (GDV)**; feed multiple smaller meals a day. Discuss diet with a vet to ensure proper nutrition for their size and life stage.
komondor.health_care: Unique corded coat needs **intense maintenance** (regular separation of cords) to prevent matting and keep it clean; cords should never be brushed. High exercise needs, but mostly an endurance walker/trotter rather than a high-speed runner. Needs an experienced, firm leader. Not suited for apartment living due to barking.
komondor.size: Height: Males >= 70 cm (27.5 in), Females >= 65 cm (25.5 in); Weight: Males >= 50 kg (100 lb), Females >= 36 kg (80 lb)
komondor.common_health_issues: Hip dysplasia, bloat (GDV), entropion (eyelid condition), generally a very robust breed.

kuvasz.nature: Protective, loyal, and independent livestock guardian. Imposing size. Suspicious of strangers and requires a firm hand in training; not ideal for first-time owners.
kuvasz.food_diet: High-quality diet. **Requires remarkably little food for their size** (easy keeper). Puppies need a controlled large-breed formula to manage growth rate and prevent orthopedic issues. Prone to **Bloat (GDV)**; feed multiple small meals.
kuvasz.health_care: Thick double coat needs **weekly brushing** (daily during heavy shedding). Coarse coat allows mud to brush off easily. Young dogs need plenty of exercise, but it diminishes with maturity. **Extensive socialization** is mandatory to prevent aggression/over-protectiveness. **Prone to roaming**.
kuvasz.size: Height: 66–76 cm (26–30 in); Weight: 32–52 kg (70–115 lb)
kuvasz.common_health_issues: Hip dysplasia, osteochondritis dissecans (OCD), bloat (GDV), patellar luxation, hereditary eye defects (cataracts, PRA).

labrador_retriever.nature: Friendly, outgoing, and loyal. Highly energetic and excels as a family pet, working dog, or service dog. **Prone to obesity**.
labrador_retriever.food_diet: High-quality, age-appropriate diet. **Highly prone to obesity**; strict portion control is essential. Puppies need large-breed food to slow growth rate. Feed two meals a day. Can have food allergies.
labrador_retriever.health_care: Low maintenance, short coat needs **weekly brushing**. Floppy ears need regular checks/cleaning. Requires **significant daily vigorous exercise** (swimming, fetch, running). DNA testing for EIC is advised. Monitor for joint issues.
labrador_retriever.common_health_issues: Obesity, Hip and Elbow Dysplasia, Exercise-Induced Collapse (EIC), Centronuclear Myopathy (CNM), various cancers (Hemangiosarcoma), eye conditions (PRA, cataracts), ear infections.

lakeland_terrier.nature: Small to mid-size, intelligent, and independent. Interacts well with family. Known for being bold and spirited (classic terrier traits).
lakeland_terrier.food_diet: High-quality, age-appropriate diet. Monitor for obesity, a risk in less active terriers.
lakeland_terrier.health_care: Wiry, double coat needs **weekly brushing**; hand stripping a few times a year is recommended to maintain texture. Needs **daily exercise** and mental stimulation. Generally a very healthy breed.
lakeland_terrier.size: Height: approx 37 cm (14.5 in); Weight: approx 7.7 kg (approx 17 lb)
lakeland_terrier.common_health_issues: Generally a very hardy breed; no widespread, major hereditary issues reported. Potential for minor orthopedic and eye conditions (similar to other terriers).

leonberg.nature: Massive, yet gentle family companion. Low to moderate energy; loves hiking and swimming. Loyal and relatively calm. Known as the 'Gentle Lion'.
leonberg.food_diet: Giant breed food. Puppies need a **controlled large-breed formula** to ensure slow, healthy growth and prevent bone/joint diseases. Prone to **Bloat (GDV)**; feed multiple small meals.
leonberg.health_care: High shedding; requires **daily brushing** to manage the double coat. Needs at least **20–60 minutes of daily exercise** (walking, hiking). Avoid strenuous puppy exercise. **Frequent heart and bloat checks are vital**.
leonberg.common_health_issues: Bloat (GDV), osteosarcoma (bone cancer), hip and elbow dysplasia, Osteochondritis Dissecans (OCD), Panosteitis (bone pain), Addison's disease, Hypothyroidism, Dilated Cardiomyopathy (DCM).

lhasa.nature: Alert, regal, and fiercely independent. Once the watchdog of Tibetan palaces. Affectionate with family but reserved with strangers. Can be stubborn.
lhasa.food_diet: High-quality, balanced diet. Prone to obesity, which can exacerbate breathing/joint issues. Feed measured portions twice daily.
lhasa.health_care: Luxurious long coat needs **daily brushing/combing** down to the skin to prevent mats. Many owners opt for a 'puppy cut' (short trim). **Brachycephalic** (flat-faced) – prone to overheating and breathing issues. **Daily tooth brushing** is crucial (dental disease risk). Needs moderate daily exercise.
lhasa.size: Height: approx 25-28 cm (approx 10-11 in); Weight: 5.5–8 kg (12–18 lb)
lhasa.common_health_issues: Brachycephalic Airway Syndrome, eye conditions (PRA, cataracts, dry eye, Glaucoma), patellar luxation, renal dysplasia (kidney defect), dental disease.

malamute.nature: Strong, friendly, loyal, and powerful sled dog. Requires firm, consistent training and does not tolerate being left alone well (can be destructive).
malamute.food_diet: High-quality, commercially available, and complete dog food. Recommended to split the daily allowance into two meals. Consult a vet on the amount, as they can be prone to weight gain if overfed relative to their significant exercise.
malamute.health_care: Daily brushing is required, with twice-daily brushing during heavy shedding periods ('blowing coat'). Needs a minimum of **two hours of heavy daily exercise** (running, pulling activities). Secure yard is essential (strong desire to roam/pull). Requires firm, positive training and socialization. Avoid overheating.
malamute.size: Height: 58–64 cm (23–25 in); Weight: 34–39 kg (75–85 lb)
malamute.common_health_issues: Hip and elbow dysplasia, hypothyroidism, cataracts, polyneuropathy (neurological), chondrodysplasia ('dwarfism'), zinc-responsive dermatosis, bloat (GDV).

malinois.nature: Highly intelligent, protective, and energetic working dog. Highly trainable and eager to please, but requires an experienced owner due to intensity.
malinois.food_diet: High-quality, nutrient-rich diet with high-quality proteins to support high activity levels. Low-fat dog food options are beneficial for maintaining optimal weight. Feed two or more small meals to help prevent bloat (GDV).
malinois.health_care: Short coat requires regular brushing (moderate shedding). Requires **intensive, daily exercise and mental challenges** (agility, obedience, running, tracking) to prevent destructive behavior. Early and extensive socialization and consistent, positive training are mandatory. Avoid vigorous exercise around feeding times (bloat risk).
malinois.size: Height: 56–66 cm (22–26 in); Weight: 18–36 kg (40–80 lb)
malinois.common_health_issues: Hip and elbow dysplasia, bloat (GDV), eye problems (cataracts, PRA), skin allergies.

maltese_dog.nature: Gentle, affectionate, and playful toy breed. Highly people-oriented. Excellent lapdog and easy traveler.
maltese_dog.food_diet: High-quality, balanced diet for toy breeds. Puppies need frequent, small meals (3-4 times/day) to prevent **hypoglycemia** (low blood sugar). Adults need two meals daily. Prone to obesity; strict portion control is necessary.
maltese_dog.health_care: The long, white coat needs **daily brushing** and routine cleaning to prevent tear staining. **Daily tooth brushing** is crucial (very high dental disease risk). Needs moderate daily exercise (indoor play/short walks). Prone to chilling; avoid cold.
maltese_dog.size: Height: 20–25 cm (8–10 in); Weight: <= 3.6 kg (<= 8 lb)
maltese_dog.common_health_issues: Dental disease (periodontal disease), luxating patella, Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA—heart defect), liver shunts, white shaker syndrome, reverse sneezing, hypoglycemia in puppies.

mexican_hairless.nature: Ancient, calm, and affectionate. Loyal and protective; reserved with strangers. Comes in hairless and coated varieties. Known for often having missing teeth (common with hairlessness gene).
mexican_hairless.food_diet: High-quality, age-appropriate diet. Monitor for food allergies. Feed two meals daily.
mexican_hairless.health_care: Hairless variety needs **daily moisturizing/sunscreen** to protect skin from sun/drying. Coated variety needs weekly brushing. Prone to chilling; needs clothing in cold weather. Needs moderate daily exercise (long walk/play). Dental care is essential.
mexican_hairless.size: Height: 25–60 cm (10–23 in) in three sizes (Toy, Miniature, Standard); Weight: 4–14 kg (10–30 lb)
mexican_hairless.common_health_issues: Dental issues (missing teeth common), skin problems (acne, dryness, sun damage in hairless), patellar luxation, hip dysplasia (in larger sizes).

miniature_pinscher.nature: Fearless, energetic, and highly spirited ('King of Toys'). Intelligent and independent. Can be stubborn and prone to 'Min Pin terror' (rambunctiousness).
miniature_pinscher.food_diet: High-quality food with grains (e.g., brown rice) recommended to maintain healthy weight. Puppies need 3-4 small meals a day to prevent hypoglycemia. Adults can eat one or two meals daily. Use a slow-feeder bowl.
miniature_pinscher.health_care: Low maintenance; smooth, short coat needs **weekly brushing** and occasional wipe-down. Requires **ample daily exercise** (play/walks) and mental stimulation. Prone to chilling; needs protection in cold weather. Check ears weekly.
miniature_pinscher.size: Height: 25–32 cm (10–12.5 in); Weight: 3.5–5 kg (8–10 lb)
miniature_pinscher.common_health_issues: Patellar luxation, Legg-Calvé-Perthes Disease, epilepsy, hypothyroidism, progressive retinal atrophy (PRA), cervical disc disease (neck issues).

miniature_poodle.nature: Intelligent, alert, and graceful. Very active and people-oriented. Excels in training and canine sports. Good for allergy sufferers (low-shedding).
miniature_poodle.food_diet: High-quality, age-appropriate diet. Prone to getting overweight, so watch calorie consumption. Feed two measured meals daily. Swimming is excellent exercise for this breed.
miniature_poodle.health_care: Non-shedding, curly coat needs **daily brushing** to the skin to prevent mats or **professional grooming every 4–6 weeks** (most common for short trims). Requires **good daily exercise** and mental activity. Regular dental care is important.
miniature_poodle.size: Height: 25–38 cm (10–15 in); Weight: 4.5–7 kg (10–15 lb)
miniature_poodle.common_health_issues: Patellar luxation, Legg-Calve-Perthes disease, eye disorders (PRA, cataracts), epilepsy, dental disease, sebaceous adenitis (skin disease).

miniature_schnauzer.nature: Alert, obedient, and friendly. Excellent watchdog (can be vocal). Happiest when with people. Highly intelligent.
miniature_schnauzer.food_diet: Well-balanced diet. Prone to **Hyperlipidemia** (high cholesterol) and **Pancreatitis**, which may require a **low-fat and high-fiber diet** (consult vet). Feed two meals daily. Weight management is important.
miniature_schnauzer.health_care: Wiry coat needs **frequent brushing** and professional stripping/clipping. Needs cleaning around the trademark beard (food traps). Needs good daily exercise and mental stimulation. **Prone to dental disease**.
miniature_schnauzer.size: Height: 30–36 cm (12–14 in); Weight: 5–9 kg (11–20 lb)
miniature_schnauzer.common_health_issues: Pancreatitis, Hyperlipidemia (high cholesterol), cataracts (hereditary), dental disease, liver shunts, bladder stones, skin issues (comedo syndrome).

newfoundland.nature: Gentle giant, strong swimmer, and patient with children ('Nanny Dog'). Loyal, calm, and devoted. Prone to drooling and heavy shedding.
newfoundland.food_diet: Giant breed food. Puppies need a **controlled large-breed formula** to prevent orthopedic problems. High risk for **Bloat (GDV)**; feed at least twice a day using slow-feeders, and restrict exercise after meals. Prone to obesity.
newfoundland.health_care: Thick double coat needs **thorough, regular brushing** (several times a week). Needs moderate daily exercise (walks, swimming is ideal). **Requires frequent heart and bloat checks**. Does not tolerate heat well.
newfoundland.size: Height: 66–71 cm (26–28 in); Weight: 45–68 kg (100–150 lb)
newfoundland.common_health_issues: Bloat (GDV), Subaortic Stenosis (SAS—heart), Dilated Cardiomyopathy (DCM), Bone Cancer (Osteosarcoma), Hip and Elbow Dysplasia, Cystinuria (urinary stones).

norfolk_terrier.nature: Affectionate, sturdy, and fearless. One of the smallest terriers. Friendly and rarely territorial; generally good with other pets/kids.
norfolk_terrier.food_diet: High-quality, age-appropriate food. Maintaining a lean body condition is important to prevent joint issues. Feed two meals daily.
norfolk_terrier.health_care: Wiry double coat needs **weekly brushing**; requires **hand stripping** a few times per year to maintain texture. Needs daily exercise and playtime. **Daily tooth brushing** is crucial (dental disease risk). Annual heart checks are important.
norfolk_terrier.size: Height: approx 25 cm (approx 10 in); Weight: 5–5.5 kg (11–12 lb)
norfolk_terrier.common_health_issues: Myxomatous Mitral Valve Disease (MMVD—heart), dental disease, patellar luxation, hip dysplasia (generally a hardy breed).

norwegian_elkhound.nature: Strong, loyal, and hardy hunter. Independent and food-driven. Excellent watchdog (can be prone to excessive barking).
norwegian_elkhound.food_diet: High-quality, balanced diet. **Gains weight easily**; portion control is vital, as obesity exacerbates joint issues. Food-driven nature makes them highly motivated for training with treats.
norwegian_elkhound.health_care: Thick double coat needs **frequent brushing** to manage shedding (heavy bi-annually). Requires **good daily exercise** and mental stimulation. Does not tolerate heat well. Monitor for excessive urination/thirst (**Fanconi syndrome** signs).
norwegian_elkhound.size: Height: 46–52 cm (18–20.5 in); Weight: approx 22-25 kg (approx 48-55 lb)
norwegian_elkhound.common_health_issues: Fanconi Syndrome (kidney disease—early detection is critical), Progressive Retinal Atrophy (PRA), hip dysplasia, sebaceous cysts, hypothyroidism, renal dysplasia.

norwich_terrier.nature: Friendly, fearless, and spirited companion. One of the smallest terriers. Very suited for family life and generally welcoming of strangers (rarely territorial).
norwich_terrier.food_diet: High-quality, age-appropriate food. Due to their small size, diet should be carefully controlled to prevent obesity-related issues.
norwich_terrier.health_care: Wiry coat sheds moderately; requires **regular grooming** and hand stripping to maintain texture. Needs daily exercise (walks/play). **Daily tooth brushing** is necessary (prone to plaque/tartar). Suited for apartment living if exercised daily. Monitor for respiratory issues.
norwich_terrier.size: Height: approx 25 cm (approx 10 in); Weight: approx 5-5.5 kg (approx 12 lb)
norwich_terrier.common_health_issues: Upper Airway Syndrome (poorly understood respiratory condition), dental disease, epilepsy, hip dysplasia, degenerative myelopathy.

old_english_sheepdog.nature: Shaggy, smart, gentle, and adaptable. Affectionate with family but can be reserved with strangers. Needs a firm but gentle owner. Has a herding instinct.
old_english_sheepdog.food_diet: High-quality, balanced diet. Prone to obesity. Feed measured portions twice daily. Weight monitoring is important for joint health.
old_english_sheepdog.health_care: High grooming needs. Double coat requires a **thorough brushing down to the skin at least weekly** (daily is often necessary) to prevent severe mats. 'Puppy trims' reduce maintenance. Needs regular physical activity (but is not constantly high energy). **Frequent vet checks for hip/eye/thyroid issues**.
old_english_sheepdog.size: Height: Males >= 56 cm (22 in), Females >= 53 cm (21 in); Weight: 27–45 kg (60–100 lb)
old_english_sheepdog.common_health_issues: Hip dysplasia, hereditary cataracts, Progressive Retinal Atrophy (PRA), hypothyroidism, deafness, Exercise-Induced Collapse (EIC), bloat (GDV).

otterhound.nature: Large scent hound; friendly, good-natured, and boisterous with a sense of humor. Inclined to follow its nose (poor recall). Adore water and swimming.
otterhound.food_diet: Large-breed dog food. **Prone to bloating and stomach problems**; feed **smaller, more frequent meals** to minimize risk. Weight control is essential, especially when young.
otterhound.health_care: Shaggy, rough coat needs regular brushing. **Heavy shedding and drooling**. Puppies need carefully limited exercise to protect growing joints. Adults need **two hours of daily exercise** that includes walking, swimming, and sniffing (endurance is more important than speed). Must be leashed/fenced (strong scent drive).
otterhound.size: Height: 61–69 cm (24–27 in); Weight: 36–54 kg (80–120 lb)
otterhound.common_health_issues: Hip and elbow dysplasia, bloat (GDV), epilepsy, hypothyroidism.

papillon.nature: Affectionate, sociable, and highly energetic. Intelligent and trainable, but needs patience. Happiest when at the center of attention (butterfly-like ears).
papillon.food_diet: High-quality food formulated for **small breeds**. Needs nutrient-dense food due to small portion sizes. Feed two measured meals daily. Monitor treats to prevent obesity.
papillon.health_care: Low shedding. Coat needs **weekly brushing** (once or twice). Requires at least **30–60 minutes of moderate exercise** daily (walks and play). **Daily tooth brushing** is important (prone to dental issues). Needs careful handling (small size).
papillon.size: Height: 20–28 cm (8–11 in); Weight: 2–4.5 kg (5–10 lb)
papillon.common_health_issues: Patellar luxation, dental disease, Progressive Retinal Atrophy (PRA), collapsed trachea, hypoglycemia (in puppies).

pekinese.nature: Regal, dignified, and affectionate, if strong-willed. Bred as royal companions/watchdogs. Vigilant and prone to barking to warn of strangers.
pekinese.food_diet: High-quality, age-appropriate food formulated for **small/toy breeds**. **Obesity is a major risk** (makes breathing problems worse); strict weight management is vital. Feed small, measured portions daily.
pekinese.health_care: Long, double coat requires **daily brushing** down to the skin to prevent mats. **Brachycephalic** (flat-faced); extreme care needed to **avoid overheating** and strenuous exercise. Needs daily short walks/play. **Daily tooth brushing** is essential. Prone to eye injuries (prominent eyes).
pekinese.size: Height: approx 20-23 cm (approx 8-9 in); Weight: <= 6.4 kg (<= 14 lb)
pekinese.common_health_issues: Brachycephalic Airway Syndrome (BOAS), eye conditions (KCS/dry eye, Progressive Retinal Atrophy, cataracts, eye injuries), patellar luxation, dental disease, heart disease (Mitral Valve Disease).

pembroke.nature: Playful, loyal, intelligent, and highly adaptable. Has a natural herding instinct (may nip at heels). Favored by royalty.
pembroke.food_diet: High-quality, age-appropriate food. **Highly prone to obesity** (due to short stature and love of food); strictly monitor calorie intake and treats. Feed two meals daily.
pembroke.health_care: Heavy shedder; needs **regular brushing** (daily during shedding seasons). Needs daily walks and play. Due to a long back and short legs, prevent jumping off furniture and support the back when picking up to prevent **Intervertebral Disc Disease (IVDD)**. Screen for DM.
pembroke.size: Height: 25–30 cm (10–12 in); Weight: <= 14 kg (<= 30 lb)
pembroke.common_health_issues: Intervertebral Disc Disease (IVDD), Hip and Elbow Dysplasia, Degenerative Myelopathy (DM), eye disorders (cataracts, PRA), Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA—heart), bladder/kidney stones, epilepsy.

pomeranian.nature: Small, fluffy, and confident with a big personality. Lively, intelligent, and highly prone to excessive barking.
pomeranian.food_diet: Protein-rich, fresh diet formulated for **small/toy breeds**. Needs balanced, controlled portions due to **fast metabolism**. Puppies need 3-4 meals a day to prevent **hypoglycemia**. Adults need two meals. Use high-quality protein sources.
pomeranian.health_care: Thick double coat needs **daily brushing** to prevent mats. Needs a harness instead of a collar to protect the trachea. Needs **daily moderate exercise** and mental stimulation. **Daily tooth brushing** is crucial (highly prone to dental disease). Avoid excessive jumping.
pomeranian.size: Height: 15–18 cm (6–7 in); Weight: 1.8–3.5 kg (4–8 lb)
pomeranian.common_health_issues: Collapsed trachea, patellar luxation, dental disease, hypoglycemia (in puppies), Alopecia X (black skin disease), hypothyroidism, eye issues (cataracts).

pug.nature: Playful, loving, and charming. Happy-go-lucky disposition. Prone to loud snoring and breathing noises (brachycephalic).
pug.food_diet: High-quality, balanced diet. **Obesity is highly common** and dangerous (increases breathing issues/heatstroke risk); strict portion control is mandatory. Some may need a diet to manage food allergies that cause skin issues. Feed in a way that minimizes air gulping.
pug.health_care: Short coat has minimal grooming needs. **Daily cleaning and drying of facial folds** is essential to prevent skin infection/dermatitis. **Brachycephalic**; prone to **overheating**—avoid hot weather and strenuous exercise. Needs daily gentle exercise. **Daily tooth brushing** is key. **Prone to severe eye injuries** (shallow sockets).
pug.size: Height: 25–33 cm (10–13 in); Weight: 6–8 kg (14–18 lb)
pug.common_health_issues: Brachycephalic Airway Syndrome (BOAS), obesity, eye injuries (proptosis, scratches), dental disease, skin allergies/infections, Legg-Calve-Perthe Disease (LCPD), hemivertebrae (spinal deformity).

redbone.nature: Affectionate, independent, energetic, and fun-loving hunter. Distinct baying sound. Prone to a natural, musty odor. High prey drive.
redbone.food_diet: High-quality, age-appropriate diet. **Enthusiastic eaters**; prone to overeating/obesity, so monitor weight and portions. Feed **at least twice per day** (not free feeding).
